elements.content: Six new coordination polymers [Zn2(L)(OX)2] (1), [Zn2(L)(1,2-BDC)2]·2H2O (2), [Zn2(L)(1,3-BDC)2(H2O)] (3), [Zn(L)(1,4-BDC)] (4), [Zn2(L)(BPDA)2]·2.68H2O (5), and [Zn3(L)2(BTC)2(H2O)2]·3H2O (6) were obtained by hydrothermal reactions of zinc(II) sulfate heptahydrate with rigid ditopic ligand 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-4-yl)benzene (L), sodium hydroxide, or tetrabutylammonium hydroxide and the corresponding carboxylic acid, namely, oxalic acid, 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid, or 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, respectively. The complexes were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, thermogravimetric, and elemental analyses. Complexes 1 and 2 are three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with infinite two-dimensional (2D) networks pillared by L ligands, and 1 possesses rare self-penetrating mab topology, while 2 shows ins topology. Complex 3 is a 2D bilayer network with infinite one-dimensional double Zn(II)-1,3-BDC2− chains linked by L ligands. Complexes 4−6 have multifold interpenetrating 3D structures: 4 has a 5-fold interpenetrating dia net, 5 has a 4-fold interpenetrating elongated primitive cubic α-Po structure, and 6 has a 3-fold interpenetrating framework. The results showed that the structural diversity of the complexes resulted from the different carboxylate ligands. Solid state properties such as photoluminescence and thermal stability of the complexes have been investigated.

elements.content: Six novel coordination polymers have been successfully constructed from reactions of rigid ditopic imidazole-containing ligand in the presence of different carboxylate ligands with Zn(II) salts. The photoluminescence properties of the complexes were explored.

elements.content: In the past decade, much progress has been achieved in the synthesis and structural characterization of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), many of which exhibit novel topological structures, interesting properties, and potential applications. Generally, the multidentate organic ligands containing coordination sites of N and/or O donors are widely utilized as building blocks in the construction of MOFs. Among them, the ditopic and tripodal imidazole-containing ligands, for example, 1,4-di(1-imidazolyl)benzene (dib), 1-(1-imidazolyl)-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (IIMB), 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene (tib), 1,3,5-tris(imidazole-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene (titmb), and 1-(1-imidazolyl)-3,5-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (ibimb), have been widely used in our previous studies, and the results have shown that they can react with varied metal salts leading to the formation of MOFs with different structures including individual cages, one-dimensional (1D) tubes, two-dimensional (2D) networks, and three-dimensional (3D) noninterpenetrating and interpenetrating frameworks. On the other hand, the polycarboxylates, such as benzenedicarboxylate, benzenetricarboxylate, biphenyldicarboxylate, and oxalate (OX2−), are the most extensively studied organic ligands in the construction of MOFs because of their versatile coordination modes, structural diversity, and thermodynamic stability.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past decade, much progress has been achieved in the synthesis and structural characterization of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), many of which exhibit novel topological structures, interesting properties, and potential applications. Generally, the multidentate organic ligands containing coordination sites of N and/or O donors are widely utilized as building blocks in the construction of MOFs. Among them, the ditopic and tripodal imidazole-containing ligands, for example, 1,4-di(1-imidazolyl)benzene (dib), 1-(1-imidazolyl)-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (IIMB), 1,3,5-tris(1-imidazolyl)benzene (tib), 1,3,5-tris(imidazole-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene (titmb), and 1-(1-imidazolyl)-3,5-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (ibimb), have been widely used in our previous studies, and the results have shown that they can react with varied metal salts leading to the formation of MOFs with different structures including individual cages, one-dimensional (1D) tubes, two-dimensional (2D) networks, and three-dimensional (3D) noninterpenetrating and interpenetrating frameworks. On the other hand, the polycarboxylates, such as benzenedicarboxylate, benzenetricarboxylate, biphenyldicarboxylate, and oxalate (OX2-), are the most extensively studied organic ligands in the construction of MOFs because of their versatile coordination modes, structural diversity, and thermodynamic stability.

elements.content: Recent studies further demonstrated that mixed organic ligands, especially the mixed polycarboxylate and N-containing ones, with more tunable factors, are good candidates for the construction of novel MOFs. Following such a mix ligand strategy, we focus our attention in this study on reactions of ligand 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-4-yl)benzene (L) together with different carboxylate ligands and Zn(II) salts and made systematic investigation on the impact of carboxylate ligands on the structure of the complexes. Herein, we report the syntheses, crystal structures, and photoluminescence properties of six new Zn(II) coordination polymers with six different di- and tricarboxylate ligands, namely, [Zn2(L)(OX)2] (1), [Zn2(L)(1,2-BDC)2]·2H2O (2), [Zn2(L)(1,3-BDC)2(H2O)] (3), [Zn(L)(1,4-BDC)] (4), [Zn2(L)(BPDA)2]·2.68H2O (5), and [Zn3(L)2(BTC)2(H2O)2]·3H2O (6) (1,2-BDC2−, 1,2-benzenedicarboxylate; 1,3-BDC2−, 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate; 1,4-BDC2−, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; BPDA2−, 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate; and BTC3−, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate). Complexes 1−6 were characterized by elemental analysis and X-ray crystallography. The thermal stability and photoluminescence of the complexes in the solid state were investigated.

Following such a mix ligand strategy, we focus our attention in this study on reactions of ligand 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-4-yl)benzene (L) together with different carboxylate ligands and Zn(II) salts and made systematic investigation on the impact of carboxylate ligands on the structure of the complexes. Herein, we report the syntheses, crystal structures, and photoluminescence properties of six new Zn(II) coordination polymers with six different di- and tricarboxylate ligands, namely, [Zn2(L)(OX)2] (1), [Zn2(L)(1,2-BDC)2]⋅2H2O (2), [Zn2(L)(1,3-BDC)2(H2O)] (3), [Zn(L)(1,4-BDC)] (4), [Zn2(L)(BPDA)2]⋅2.68H2O (5), and [Zn3(L)2(BTC)2(H2O)2]⋅3H2O (6) (1,2-BDC2-, 1,2-benzenedicarboxylate; 1,3-BDC2-, 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate; 1,4-BDC2-, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; BPDA2-, 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate; and BTC3-, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate). Complexes 1-6 were characterized by elemental analysis and X-ray crystallography. The thermal stability and photoluminescence of the complexes in the solid state were investigated.

elements.content: All of the commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. The ligand L was synthesized according to the literature. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C Elemental Analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded in the range of 400−4000 cm−1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. The luminescence spectra for the powdered solid samples were measured on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. In the measurements of emission and excitation spectra, the pass width is 5 nm, and all of the measurements were carried out under the same experimental conditions. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature.

Experimental Section

All of the commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. The ligand L was synthesized according to the literature. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C Elemental Analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. The luminescence spectra for the powdered solid samples were measured on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. In the measurements of emission and excitation spectra, the pass width is 5 nm, and all of the measurements were carried out under the same experimental conditions. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature.

elements.content: A mixture of L (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), ZnSO4·7H2O (57.6 mg, 0.2 mmol), H2C2O4·2H2O (25.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), and NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.4 mmol) in 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 160 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals of 1 were collected with a yield of 62% by filtration and washed with water and ethanol several times. Anal. calcd for C8H5N2O4Zn: C, 37.14; H, 1.93; N, 10.83%. elements.content: The crystallographic data collections for 1−3 and 6 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD area detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using ω-scan technique. The diffraction data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which was also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all of the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically except that H1A and H1B of the water molecule in 2 were found at reasonable positions in the differential Fourier map and located there. The crystallographic data for 4 and 5 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at 200 K, with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods with SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full matrix least-squares method on F 2. All of the hydrogen atoms of 4 and 5 in the structure were generated geometrically except that H1 and H2 atoms of the water molecules in 5, which were found at reasonable positions in the differential Fourier map. All calculations were carried out on SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corporation. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for the complexes are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations are listed in Table .

Crystallography

The crystallographic data collections for 1-3 and 6 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD area detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using ω-scan technique. The diffraction data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which was also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all of the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically except that H1A and H1B of the water molecule in 2 were found at reasonable positions in the differential Fourier map and located there. The crystallographic data for 4 and 5 were collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at 200 K, with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods with SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full matrix least-squares method on F 2. All of the hydrogen atoms of 4 and 5 in the structure were generated geometrically except that H1 and H2 atoms of the water molecules in 5, which were found at reasonable positions in the differential Fourier map. All calculations were carried out on SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corporation. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for the complexes are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations are listed in Table .

The results of crystallographic analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of complex 1 consists of one Zn(II) atom, one OX2−, and half molecule of L ligand. As shown in Figure a, the central Zn(II) atom is 6-coordinated with distorted octahedral coordination geometry by five oxygen atoms (O1, O4, O2A, O3A, and O3B) from three different OX2− anions and one nitrogen atom (N1) from a L ligand, with Zn1−O bond distances ranging from 2.071(2) to 2.239(2) Å and Zn1−N one of 2.039(3) Å, respectively (Table ). As it is known, the OX2− is a versatile multidentate bridging ligand due to its diverse coordination modes of the carboxylate groups. In complex 1, it is noteworthy that the two carboxylate groups of each OX2− ligand adopt different coordination modes to connect three Zn(II) atoms: one with μ2-η1:η1-bidentate bridging mode and the other one with μ3-η1:η2-mode (type I, Scheme ). If the connections through the L ligands are ignored, the OX2− ligands coordinate with Zn(II) atoms to form a 2D network with (4, 4) topology by considering the Zn2O2 units as network nodes (Figure b). Each rhombus grid of ABCD has a edge distance of 6.13 Å, and the angle of A−B−C is 96.38°. The 2D layers are further linked together by L ligands to form a 3D structure (Figure c).

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn2(L)(OX)2] (1)

The results of crystallographic analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of complex 1 consists of one Zn(II) atom, one OX2-, and half molecule of L ligand. As shown in Figure a, the central Zn(II) atom is 6-coordinated with distorted octahedral coordination geometry by five oxygen atoms (O1, O4, O2A, O3A, and O3B) from three different OX2- anions and one nitrogen atom (N1) from a L ligand, with Zn1-O bond distances ranging from 2.071(2) to 2.239(2) Å and Zn1-N one of 2.039(3) Å, respectively (Table ). As it is known, the OX2- is a versatile multidentate bridging ligand due to its diverse coordination modes of the carboxylate groups. In complex 1, it is noteworthy that the two carboxylate groups of each OX2- ligand adopt different coordination modes to connect three Zn(II) atoms: one with μ2-η1:η1-bidentate bridging mode and the other one with μ3-η1:η2-mode (type I, Scheme ). If the connections through the L ligands are ignored, the OX2- ligands coordinate with Zn(II) atoms to form a 2D network with (4, 4) topology by considering the Zn2O2 units as network nodes (Figure b). Each rhombus grid of ABCD has a edge distance of 6.13 Å, and the angle of A-B-C is 96.38°. The 2D layers are further linked together by L ligands to form a 3D structure (Figure c).

elements.content: To further understand the structure of the complex, topological analysis by reducing multidimensional structure to simple node-and-linker net was performed on 1. Taking the geometrical center of the Zn2O2 binuclear unit as a network node, it is linked by four OX2− ligands in the bc plane and two L ligands along the +a and −a crystal directions; hence, each Zn2O2 binuclear unit can be described as a 6-connected node. Meanwhile, both OX2− and L ligands connect two binuclear Zn(II) centers; thus, both of them can be treated as 2-connected nodes. According to the simplification principle, the resulting structure of 1 is a rare reported mab framework with (44·610·8) topology (Figure d). This particular topology has been observed in a supramolecular net formed by the salt {[Co(H2O)4(Hdpa)2][pyro]} (dpa, 4,4′-dipyridylamine; pyro, pyromellitate) but seldom in the coordination polymer family. A closer examination of a portion of the network reveals that it is a self-penetrating network, that is, some of the “shortest circuits” of the network are penetrated by links in the same network. As highlighted in Figure d, there are 6-membered shortest circuits that penetrate each other. Thus, 1 can be considered as another example of the self-penetrated coordination polymers.

elements.content: When 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid, instead of oxalic acid, was used in the reaction, complex 2 was isolated. As shown in Figure a, each Zn(II) atom is 4-coordinated with a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry, rather than the 6-coordinated octahedral one that appeared in 1, by three oxygen atoms (O2, O3A, and O4B) from three different 1,2-BDC2− ligands and one nitrogen atom (N1) from one L ligand. The Zn−O bond lengths are in the range of 1.950(2)−2.0022(19) Å, and the Zn−N one is 1.989(2) Å (Table ), which is consistent with the reported 4-coordinated Zn(II) complexes with O and N donors. The bond angles around Zn(II) atoms are in the range of 93.17(9)−122.23(10)° (Table ). On the other hand, each 1,2-BDC2− connects three Zn(II) atoms using its two carboxylate groups with μ2-η1:η1-bidentate and μ1-η1:η0 -monodentate coordination modes, respectively (type II, Scheme ). If the connections through the L ligands are neglected, four Zn(II) atoms are interlinked by the three 1,2-BDC2− ligands to form a grid, which are further connected together into a 2D puckered (4, 4) net (Figure b). In each Zn4 grid, the Zn···Zn edge distances are 5.05 Å for Zn1A···Zn1B and Zn1C···Zn1D and 6.30 Å for Zn1B···Zn1C and Zn1A···Zn1D, respectively, and the angles formed between the Zn(II) nodes (e.g., Zn1B−Zn1A−Zn1D and Zn1A−Zn1B−Zn1C) are 73.74 and 106.26°, respectively, which can be seen clearly from a simplified 2D network where only the Zn(II) atoms are presented (Figure b). Furthermore, the 2D layers are linked together by L ligands to generate a 3D structure (Figure c).

elements.content: Similar topological analysis was carried out to analyze the structure of 2. As discussed above, each 1,2-BDC2− and L ligand link three and two Zn(II) atoms, respectively, accordingly the 1,2-BDC2− and L can be regarded as a 3- and 2-connected nodes, respectively. As for each Zn(II) atom, it in turn links three 1,2-BDC2− and one L ligand; hence, it can be treated as a 4-connector. According to the simplification principle, the resulting structure of the complex 2 is a binodal (3, 4)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol (63)(65·8), which has been referred to by O'Keeffe and Wells as the ins notation (Figure d).

elements.content: When 1,2-H2BDC was replaced by 1,3-H2BDC in the reaction, complex 3 with different structure was obtained. The polymeric structure of 3 was evidenced by X-ray single-crystal structure determination. Figure a shows the coordination environment of two independent Zn(II) atoms with the atom numbering scheme. It can be clearly seen that the Zn1 atom is in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment with three oxygen atoms (O2, O6, and O4A) from three different 1,3-BDC2− ligands with Zn1−O4A, Zn1−O6, and Zn1−O2 bond distances of 1.928(2), 1.947(2), and 2.029(3) Å, respectively, and one nitrogen atom (N2) from L ligand with a Zn1−N2 bond distance of 2.001(3) Å (Table ). The Zn2 atom adopts a distorted square-pyramidal geometry by coordination of three oxygen atoms (O1, O2, and O8A) from two 1,3-BDC2− ligands, one terminal water molecule (O1W), and one nitrogen atom (N4B) from the L ligand. There are two different 1,3-BDC2− ligands in the asymmetric unit of 3 with different coordination modes (types III and IV, Scheme ). One 1,3-BDC2− is in a μ2-bridging fashion with each carboxylate group in μ1-η1:η0-monodentate mode (Type III, Scheme ). The other one is a μ3-bridge with one carboxylate group in μ1-η1:η0-monodentate mode and the other one in μ2-η2:η1-fashion (type IV, Scheme ). It is noticeable that the carboxylate O2 atom of the 1,3-BDC2− ligand act as bridge in 3 to link two zinc(II) atoms (Zn1 and Zn2, Figure a) with a Zn···Zn distance of 3.4908(9) Å.

Crystal Structure of [Zn2(L)(1,3-BDC)2(H2O)] (3)

When 1,2-H2BDC was replaced by 1,3-H2BDC in the reaction, complex 3 with different structure was obtained. The polymeric structure of 3 was evidenced by X-ray single-crystal structure determination. Figure a shows the coordination environment of two independent Zn(II) atoms with the atom numbering scheme. It can be clearly seen that the Zn1 atom is in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment with three oxygen atoms (O2, O6, and O4A) from three different 1,3-BDC2- ligands with Zn1-O4A, Zn1-O6, and Zn1-O2 bond distances of 1.928(2), 1.947(2), and 2.029(3) Å, respectively, and one nitrogen atom (N2) from L ligand with a Zn1-N2 bond distance of 2.001(3) Å (Table ). The Zn2 atom adopts a distorted square-pyramidal geometry by coordination of three oxygen atoms (O1, O2, and O8A) from two 1,3-BDC2- ligands, one terminal water molecule (O1W), and one nitrogen atom (N4B) from the L ligand. There are two different 1,3-BDC2- ligands in the asymmetric unit of 3 with different coordination modes (types III and IV, Scheme ). One 1,3-BDC2- is in a μ2-bridging fashion with each carboxylate group in μ1-η1:η0-monodentate mode (Type III, Scheme ). The other one is a μ3-bridge with one carboxylate group in μ1-η1:η0-monodentate mode and the other one in μ2-η2:η1-fashion (type IV, Scheme ). It is noticeable that the carboxylate O2 atom of the 1,3-BDC2- ligand act as bridge in 3 to link two zinc(II) atoms (Zn1 and Zn2, Figure a) with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 3.4908(9) Å.

elements.content: If the connections through the L ligands are ignored, the 1,3-BDC2− ligands link Zn(II) atoms using its carboxylate groups to form a 1D double chain (Figure b). The 1D chains are further linked through the L ligands resulting in formation of a 2D double-layer network (Figure c, left). There are 60-membered macrocycles in the 2D sheet, formed by two L and four 1,3-BDC2− ligands together with six Zn(II) atoms. As discussed above, one L ligand links two Zn(II) atoms, and one 1,3-BDC2− ligand links two, while the other one connects three Zn(II) atoms; thus, they can be treated as 2-, 2-, and 3-connectors, respectively. On the other hand, the Zn1 atom in turn links two 1,3-BDC2− and two L ligands; hence, it can be treated as 4-connector, while the Zn2 atom adopts 3-connectors to link two 1,3-BDC2− and one L ligands. According to the simplification principle, the resulting structure of 3 is a trinodal (3, 4)-connected net with a (5·6·7)(52·6·7·82)(52·8) topology (Figure c, right). Moreover, the 2D layers are further linked together by C−H···O, O−H···O, and O−H···N hydrogen bonds to generate a 3D structure (Figure S1 of the ). The hydrogen bonding data are summarized in Table S1 of the .

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction study revealed that the asymmetric unit of 4 contains one unique Zn(II) atom coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N12 and N12A) from two different L ligands and two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 and O1A) from two different 1,4-BDC2−, thereby forming a 4-coordinated tetrahedral coordination geometry with a N2O2 donor set (Figure a). The Zn1−N and Zn1−O distances are 2.0007(13) and 1.9605(12) Å, respectively, and the coordination angles around Zn1 are in the range of 105.68(8)−112.69(8)° (Table ). If the connections through L ligands are ignored, each 1,4-BDC2− ligand acts as a μ2-bridge to link two Zn(II) atoms (type V, Scheme ), forming an infinite chain structure, and the 1D chains are linked together by L ligands to form a 2D network in the ac plane as shown in Figure b. Such 2D networks are further connected by alternating 1,4-BDC2− ligands along the b-axis to generate the 3D framework (Figure c). Considering the Zn(II) atom as a 4-connecting node and the L, 1,4-BDC2− ligands as linkers, the overall structure of 4 is a diamond framework (dia net) containing large adamantanoid cages as illustrated in Figure d. There are large channels of 16.35 Å × 29.07 Å expanded from the diamondiod net (Figure c), which can be seen clearly from the space-filling diagram of a single unit (Figure e). The large vacancy of the diamond net facilitates the interpenetration. As for the complex 4, the large cavities are completely filled via mutual interpenetration of the independent frameworks, leading to the formation of a 5-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure f).

Crystal Structure of [Zn(L)(1,4-BDC)] (4)

The X-ray diffraction study revealed that the asymmetric unit of 4 contains one unique Zn(II) atom coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N12 and N12A) from two different L ligands and two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 and O1A) from two different 1,4-BDC2-, thereby forming a 4-coordinated tetrahedral coordination geometry with a N2O2 donor set (Figure a). The Zn1-N and Zn1-O distances are 2.0007(13) and 1.9605(12) Å, respectively, and the coordination angles around Zn1 are in the range of 105.68(8)-112.69(8)° (Table ). If the connections through L ligands are ignored, each 1,4-BDC2- ligand acts as a μ2-bridge to link two Zn(II) atoms (type V, Scheme ), forming an infinite chain structure, and the 1D chains are linked together by L ligands to form a 2D network in the ac plane as shown in Figure b. Such 2D networks are further connected by alternating 1,4-BDC2- ligands along the b-axis to generate the 3D framework (Figure c). Considering the Zn(II) atom as a 4-connecting node and the L, 1,4-BDC2- ligands as linkers, the overall structure of 4 is a diamond framework (dia net) containing large adamantanoid cages as illustrated in Figure d. There are large channels of 16.35 Å × 29.07 Å expanded from the diamondiod net (Figure c), which can be seen clearly from the space-filling diagram of a single unit (Figure e). The large vacancy of the diamond net facilitates the interpenetration. As for the complex 4, the large cavities are completely filled via mutual interpenetration of the independent frameworks, leading to the formation of a 5-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure f).

elements.content: When the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid was changed to the 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid, complex 5 with different structure and topology was obtained. The asymmetric unit of 5 contains one Zn(II) atom, half L Ligand, one BPDA2− ligand, and 1.34 free water molecules. The Zn(II) atom is 4-coordinated with distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry (Figure a) defined by one nitrogen atom (N12) from one L ligand and three oxygen atoms (O1, O2A, and O3B) from three different BPDA2− ligands. The Zn1−O distances are 1.942(2), 1.945(2), and 1.974(2) Å, and the Zn1−N one is 1.977(3) Å, respectively (Table ). In this complex, each BPDA2− ligand acts as μ3-bridge to link three Zn(II) atoms (type VI, Scheme ), one carboxylate group adopts a μ2-η1:η1-bridging coordination mode, while the other one adopts μ1-η1:η0-coordination mode. Two such carboxylate groups from different BPDA2− ligands bridge two Zn(II) atoms to give a binuclear [Zn2(COO)2] motif, with the Zn···Zn distance of 3.69 Å. Meanwhile, each Zn2(COO)2 binuclear unit links two L and four BPDA2− ligands to form a 6-connected node as secondary building unit (SBU) (Figure b). When the connections via the L ligands are ignored, the Zn2(COO)2 binuclear motifs are linked through the BPDA2− ligands, leading to the formation of a 2D coordination network (Figure c). Taking the Zn2(COO)2 binuclear motifs as network nodes and the BPDA2− ligands as linkers, the layer can be considered as a (4, 4) square grid, and the 2D square grids are pillared by L molecules to form a 3D framework with α-Po 412·63 topology that possesses elongated primitive cubelike units with dimensions 15.23 Å × 15.44 Å × 17.05 Å (Figure d). Of particular interest, the most striking feature of complex 5 is that four identical 3D nets are interlocked each other, leading to the formation of a 4-fold interpenetrated 3D to 3D architecture (Figure e). Despite the 4-fold interpenetration, the total void value of the channel without water guests is estimated (by PLATON) to be 323.8 Å3, approximately 17.1% of the total crystal volume of 1896.2 Å3 (Figure S2 of the ).

elements.content: In addition to the dicarboxylate ligands, tricarboxylic acid, that is, H3BTC, was also used in the reaction, and complex 6 was isolated. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 6 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. As shown in Figure a, there are two different Zn(II) atoms in the asymmetric unit of 6. Zn1 is 4-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N3A and N3B) from two L ligands and two oxygen atoms (O5 and O5C) from two different BTC3− ligands. The Zn1−O and Zn1−N distances are 1.963(14) and 2.027(16), respectively, and the coordination angles around Zn1 vary from 93.13(6) to 126.00(9)° (Table ). Zn2 is coordinated by two oxygen atoms (O1 and O3D) from two different BTC3− ligands, one oxygen atom (O1W) from a water molecule, and one nitrogen atom (N1) from L to complete a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment. The Zn2−O distances are in range of 1.953(16)−2.026(17) Å, and the Zn2−N distance is 1.972(17) Å, while the bond angles around Zn2 vary from 96.04(7) to 137.90(7) (Table ). In 6, each completely deprotonated BTC3− serves as a 3-connected node to coordinate with three Zn(II) atoms through its each carboxylate group in a μ1-η1:η0-monodentate coordination mode (Scheme , VII), generating a 1D ladderlike chain (Figure b). Furthermore, the Zn(II) atoms are in turn connected by L and BTC3− to give rise to the complicated 3D framework, showing 1D square channels with a pore diameter approximately 6 Å (Figure c). As a result, interpenetration is usually found in MOFs containing large cavities, and the 3D networks of 6 interlock each other, leading to the formation of a 3-fold interpenetration networks as illustrated in Figure d.

elements.content: Six Zn(II) coordination polymers were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized using rigid ditopic ligand L as bridging ligand in the presence of multicarboxylate anions. The pure phases of complexes 1−6 were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction measurements (Figure S4 of the ). The complexes possess mab, ins, dia, pcu, and other net topologies, respectively, based on the topological analysis. It is clear that the distinct framework structures are ascribed to the different coordination modes of the carboxylate ligands. The carboxylate group is not only used as the effective organic linkers but also as a counteranion in the construction of MOFs, so the anions of the metal salts usually do not participate in the formation of the complexes. The rigid bridging imidazolyl ligand L utilizes two terminal N atoms to coordinate with Zn(II) atoms just like a linker. As a result, complexes 1, 2, and 5 are pillared into 3D networks, while 3 into 2D double-layer framework. Interestingly, both complexes 1 and 5 contain 2D (4, 4) sheets bridged by bidentate “pillars” similarly; however, they have different structures. In 5, the pillars are parallel and connect the sheets into α-Po type networks, while in 1, the pillar ligands criss-cross bridge at two different angles relative to sheets, giving a rare mab type network.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of the Structures

Six Zn(II) coordination polymers were successfully synthesized and structurally characterized using rigid ditopic ligand L as bridging ligand in the presence of multicarboxylate anions. The pure phases of complexes 1-6 were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction measurements (Figure S4 of the ). The complexes possess mab, ins, dia, pcu, and other net topologies, respectively, based on the topological analysis. It is clear that the distinct framework structures are ascribed to the different coordination modes of the carboxylate ligands. The carboxylate group is not only used as the effective organic linkers but also as a counteranion in the construction of MOFs, so the anions of the metal salts usually do not participate in the formation of the complexes. The rigid bridging imidazolyl ligand L utilizes two terminal N atoms to coordinate with Zn(II) atoms just like a linker. As a result, complexes 1, 2, and 5 are pillared into 3D networks, while 3 into 2D double-layer framework. Interestingly, both complexes 1 and 5 contain 2D (4, 4) sheets bridged by bidentate "pillars" similarly; however, they have different structures. In 5, the pillars are parallel and connect the sheets into α-Po type networks, while in 1, the pillar ligands criss-cross bridge at two different angles relative to sheets, giving a rare mab type network.

elements.content: Usually, it is widely acknowledged that long spacer ligands often favor the formation of interpenetrated motifs. Particularly, complexes 4−6 constructed from the rigid L and carboxylate ligands also exhibit interpenetrating frameworks. As depicted in the 3D single nets of 4−6 above, there exist large cavity in which frameworks tend to be interpenetrated to fill the void space. In this case, complexes 4−6 exhibit 5, 4, and 3-fold interpenetrations, respectively. In addition, 5 has a different topology with the long bridging ligand BPDA2− as compared with the coordination polymer 4 with short 1,4-BDC2− ligand.

elements.content: The mixed polycarboxylate and N donor ligands have been proven to be useful in construction of MOFs with novel structures and unique properties. For example, the magnetic property of the Mn(II) framework with oxylate and titmb ligands has been studied, and porous MOFs with dicarboxylate and pyrazolate- or pyridyl-containing ligands showed gas adsorption property. A systematic study was carried out in this work by using varied carboxylate ligands, and MOFs with different structure and topology were obtained. The results provide a nice example of the construction of MOFs using mix ligand strategy. On the other hand, assembly reactions of organic ligands with metal salts are known to be influenced by factors such as solvents, reaction pH, and/or temperature and so on. Particularly, coordination modes of carboxylates can be influenced by the solvents used in the reaction media, and further studies on MOFs with L and carboxylate ligands are going on.

elements.content: Complexes 1−6 were subjected to TGA to ascertain the stability of their respective supramolecular architectures (Figure S3 of the ). Complex 2 shows a weight loss of 5.22% around 200 °C corresponding to the release of free water molecules (calcd 5.11%) and the decomposition of the residue occurred at 300 °C. For 3, a weight loss of 2.91% was observed in the temperature range of 130−160 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the coordinated water molecules (calcd 2.62%), and further weight loss was observed at about 340 °C. For 5, a weight loss starts at 240 °C with the liberation of the free water molecules with a weight of 5.72% (calcd 5.55%), and the decomposition of the residue observed at about 390 °C. A total weight loss of 8.10% was observed for 6 in the temperature range of 120−220 °C, which is attributed to the loss of both the coordinated and the uncoordinated water molecules (calcd 8.03%), and the residue is stable up to about 470 °C. No obvious weight losses were found for complexes 1 and 4 before the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 405 and 470 °C, respectively, which are in good agreement with the results of the crystal structure. From a high decomposing temperature of the complexes, it can further support the conclusion that rigid robustness of the ligands benefits the thermal stability of the framework. As for the compounds 4−6, their decomposing temperatures are above 390 °C, which are in accord with their interpenetrating structure feature. Because its large cavity makes it less stable, the decomposing temperature of the complex 5 is lower than those of complexes 4 and 6, which also fits in with its special structure.

Thermal Stabilities of the Complexes

Complexes 1-6 were subjected to TGA to ascertain the stability of their respective supramolecular architectures (Figure S3 of the ). Complex 2 shows a weight loss of 5.22% around 200 °C corresponding to the release of free water molecules (calcd 5.11%) and the decomposition of the residue occurred at 300 °C. For 3, a weight loss of 2.91% was observed in the temperature range of 130-160 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the coordinated water molecules (calcd 2.62%), and further weight loss was observed at about 340 °C. For 5, a weight loss starts at 240 °C with the liberation of the free water molecules with a weight of 5.72% (calcd 5.55%), and the decomposition of the residue observed at about 390 °C. A total weight loss of 8.10% was observed for 6 in the temperature range of 120-220 °C, which is attributed to the loss of both the coordinated and the uncoordinated water molecules (calcd 8.03%), and the residue is stable up to about 470 °C. No obvious weight losses were found for complexes 1 and 4 before the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 405 and 470 °C, respectively, which are in good agreement with the results of the crystal structure. From a high decomposing temperature of the complexes, it can further support the conclusion that rigid robustness of the ligands benefits the thermal stability of the framework. As for the compounds 4-6, their decomposing temperatures are above 390 °C, which are in accord with their interpenetrating structure feature. Because its large cavity makes it less stable, the decomposing temperature of the complex 5 is lower than those of complexes 4 and 6, which also fits in with its special structure.

elements.content: Coordination polymers have been reported to have the ability to adjust the emission wavelength of organic materials through incorporation of metal centers, especially for the d 10 metal centers. So, it gives us an impetus to make an investigation on the luminescence properties of coordination polymers in view of potential applications as photoactive materials. The photoluminescence properties of Zn(II) complexes 1−6, together with the L ligand and all of the carboxylic acids, were studied in the solid state at room temperature. The emission spectra of the complexes and L ligand are depicted in Figure S5 of the . It can be seen that all of the complexes 1−6 exhibit emissions under the experimental conditions. Emission bands were observed at 470 nm (λex = 410 nm) for 1, 485 nm (λex = 390 nm) for 2, 487 nm (λex = 400 nm) for 3, 500 nm (λex = 425 nm) for 4, 435 nm (λex = 368 nm) for 5, 458 nm (λex = 390 nm) for 6, respectively. Such fluorescent emissions may be tentatively assigned to intraligand transition of coordinated L ligands, since similar emission at 456 nm (λex = 341 nm) was observed for the L ligand. The red- and blue-shifted emissions of 1−6 were caused by the coordination of the ligands to the metal centers. Emissions were also observed at ca. 345 nm for H2OX and at 390−400 nm for 1,2-H2BDC, 1,3-H2BDC, 1,4-H2BDC, H2BPDA, and H3BTC as reported previously. However, the emission bands of the carboxylate ligands originated from the π* → n transition are weak, and it was considered that the carboxylate ligands have no significant contribution to the fluorescent emission of the coordination polymers 1−6 with the presence of N donor ligand.

Photoluminescence Property

Coordination polymers have been reported to have the ability to adjust the emission wavelength of organic materials through incorporation of metal centers, especially for the d 10 metal centers. So, it gives us an impetus to make an investigation on the luminescence properties of coordination polymers in view of potential applications as photoactive materials. The photoluminescence properties of Zn(II) complexes 1-6, together with the L ligand and all of the carboxylic acids, were studied in the solid state at room temperature. The emission spectra of the complexes and L ligand are depicted in Figure S5 of the . It can be seen that all of the complexes 1-6 exhibit emissions under the experimental conditions. Emission bands were observed at 470 nm (λex = 410 nm) for 1, 485 nm (λex = 390 nm) for 2, 487 nm (λex = 400 nm) for 3, 500 nm (λex = 425 nm) for 4, 435 nm (λex = 368 nm) for 5, 458 nm (λex = 390 nm) for 6, respectively. Such fluorescent emissions may be tentatively assigned to intraligand transition of coordinated L ligands, since similar emission at 456 nm (λex = 341 nm) was observed for the L ligand. The red- and blue-shifted emissions of 1-6 were caused by the coordination of the ligands to the metal centers. Emissions were also observed at ca. 345 nm for H2OX and at 390-400 nm for 1,2-H2BDC, 1,3-H2BDC, 1,4-H2BDC, H2BPDA, and H3BTC as reported previously. However, the emission bands of the carboxylate ligands originated from the π* → n transition are weak, and it was considered that the carboxylate ligands have no significant contribution to the fluorescent emission of the coordination polymers 1-6 with the presence of N donor ligand.

elements.content: Six new coordination polymers with different topologies and framework structures have been successfully constructed based on the rigid ligand and varied carboxylates together with Zn(II) salts under hydrothermal conditions. The results suggest that the structural diversification of coordination polymers may result from the varied polycarboxylate ligands. Moreover, complexes 1−6 exhibit photoluminescence properties, which appear to be potential hybrid inorganic−organic photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Six new coordination polymers with different topologies and framework structures have been successfully constructed based on the rigid ligand and varied carboxylates together with Zn(II) salts under hydrothermal conditions. The results suggest that the structural diversification of coordination polymers may result from the varied polycarboxylate ligands. Moreover, complexes 1-6 exhibit photoluminescence properties, which appear to be potential hybrid inorganic-organic photoactive materials.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of L (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), ZnSO4·7H2O (57.6 mg, 0.2 mmol), H2C2O4·2H2O (25.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), and NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.4 mmol) in 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 160 °C for 3 days. Colorless block crystals of 1 were collected with a yield of 62% by filtration and washed with water and ethanol several times. Anal. calcd for C8H5N2O4Zn: C, 37.14; H, 1.93; N, 10.83%. Found: C, 37.18; H, 1.89; N, 10.87%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3312 (m, br), 1677 (s), 1510 (m), 1474 (m), 1447 (m), 1360 (m), 1316 (s), 1141(s), 1077 (m), 950 (m), 880 (w), 817 (m), 797 (s), 644(s), 490 (m), 415 (m).

Preparation of [Zn<sub>2</sub>(L)(1,2-BDC)<sub>2</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

Complex 2 was obtained by hydrothermal procedure as that for preparation of 1 just using 1, 2-H2BDC (33.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) instead of H2C2O4·2H2O as the starting reactant. Colorless block crystals of 2 were collected in 48% yield after washed by water and ethanol several times. Anal. Calcd for C14H11N2O5Zn: C, 47.64; H, 3.12; N, 7.94%. Found: C, 47.72; H, 3.09; N, 7.80%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3148 (w, br), 1616 (s), 1590 (s), 1536 (s), 1448 (m), 1423 (m), 1386(s), 1295 (w), 1270 (w), 1137 (s), 1106 (w), 1070 (w), 968 (w), 847 (s), 818 (s), 764 (m), 712 (s), 659 (m), 598 (w), 488 (w).

Preparation of [Zn<sub>2</sub>(L)(1,3-BDC)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>3</bold>)

The title complex was obtained by a similar procedure to that used for preparation of 2 except for using 1,3-H2BDC (33.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) instead of 1,2-H2BDC as starting material. Colorless block crystals of 3 were isolated and washed by water and ethanol several times in 41% yield. Anal. Calcd for C28H18N4O9Zn2: C, 48.91; H, 2.62; N, 8.15%. Found: C, 48.75; H, 2.73; N, 7.99%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3137 (w), 1615 (s), 1578 (s), 1428 (m), 1397 (s), 1340 (m), 1173 (w), 1072(w), 950(w), 814 (w), 741 (m), 721 (m), 646 (w), 472 (w).

Preparation of [Zn(L)(1,4-BDC)] (<bold>4</bold>)

Complex 4 was obtained by a similar hydrothermal procedure used for the synthesis of 2 except that 1,4-H2BDC (33.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) was used instead of 1,2-H2BDC as the starting reactant. cln_elements.content:
Complexes 1−6 were subjected to TGA to ascertain the stability of their respective supramolecular architectures (Figure S3 of the ). Complex 2 shows a weight loss of 5.22% around 200 °C corresponding to the release of free water molecules (calcd 5.11%) and the decomposition of the residue occurred at 300 °C. For 3, a weight loss of 2.91% was observed in the temperature range of 130−160 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the coordinated water molecules (calcd 2.62%), and further weight loss was observed at about 340 °C. For 5, a weight loss starts at 240 °C with the liberation of the free water molecules with a weight of 5.72% (calcd 5.55%), and the decomposition of the residue observed at about 390 °C. A total weight loss of 8.10% was observed for 6 in the temperature range of 120−220 °C, which is attributed to the loss of both the coordinated and the uncoordinated water molecules (calcd 8.03%), and the residue is stable up to about 470 °C. No obvious weight losses were found for complexes 1 and 4 before the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 405 and 470 °C, respectively, which are in good agreement with the results of the crystal structure. From a high decomposing temperature of the complexes, it can further support the conclusion that rigid robustness of the ligands benefits the thermal stability of the framework. As for the compounds 4−6, their decomposing temperatures are above 390 °C, which are in accord with their interpenetrating structure feature. Because its large cavity makes it less stable, the decomposing temperature of the complex 5 is lower than those of complexes 4 and 6, which also fits in with its special structure.

Photoluminescence Property

Coordination polymers have been reported to have the ability to adjust the emission wavelength of organic materials through incorporation of metal centers, especially for the d 10 metal centers. So, it gives us an impetus to make an investigation on the luminescence properties of coordination polymers in view of potential applications as photoactive materials. The photoluminescence properties of Zn(II) complexes 1−6, together with the L ligand and all of the carboxylic acids, were studied in the solid state at room temperature. The emission spectra of the complexes and L ligand are depicted in Figure S5 of the . It can be seen that all of the complexes 1−6 exhibit emissions under the experimental conditions. Emission bands were observed at 470 nm (λex = 410 nm) for 1, 485 nm (λex = 390 nm) for 2, 487 nm (λex = 400 nm) for 3, 500 nm (λex = 425 nm) for 4, 435 nm (λex = 368 nm) for 5, 458 nm (λex = 390 nm) for 6, respectively. Such fluorescent emissions may be tentatively assigned to intraligand transition of coordinated L ligands, since similar emission at 456 nm (λex = 341 nm) was observed for the L ligand. The red- and blue-shifted emissions of 1−6 were caused by the coordination of the ligands to the metal centers. Emissions were also observed at ca. 345 nm for H2OX and at 390−400 nm for 1,2-H2BDC, 1,3-H2BDC, 1,4-H2BDC, H2BPDA, and H3BTC as reported previously. However, the emission bands of the carboxylate ligands originated from the π* → n transition are weak, and it was considered that the carboxylate ligands have no significant contribution to the fluorescent emission of the coordination polymers 1−6 with the presence of N donor ligand.
